citations.narrative:
A significant accumulation of rodent droppings were observed on the floor of the shed used for storing unopened bags of
dog food. The bags of feed were stored directly on the ground and droppings were present on the floor surrounding the
bags as well as on a chair adjacent to the bags. There were no traps or bait stations present in the area.
Food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin
infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls to allow for cleaning beneath and around
the supplies. The licensee must also develop an effective pest control program to reduce contamination by pests in both
animal and food storage areas.
To be corrected by: January 23, 2026

An adult female poodle (Hershey, M/C number 901001000072972) has excessively long toenails on all four feet. The
licensee stated that they did not have a set schedule for checking and trimming toenails on the dogs. An adult male
poodle (Reuben, M/C number 933000321000501) also has excessively long nails on all four feet. Multiple large mats
were present on both hind legs and feet. Matted coats may cause discomfort to the animal and result in irritation of the
skin beneath the mats. Excessively long toenails are more likely to break or get caught in the grated flooring of the
enclosure and result in injury. Long toenails can also result in pain and difficulty walking or standing normally.
The current program of veterinary care states that both nails and haircoats are to be checked every 2 to 4 months.
The licensee must follow their preventative care plan to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails,
and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The licensee must have these dogs groomed to address the long
toenails and matting.
To be corrected by: January 16, 2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A significant accumulation of rodent droppings were observed on the floor of the shed used for storing unopened bags of 
dog food. The bags of feed were stored directly on the ground and droppings were present on the floor surrounding the 
bags as well as on a chair adjacent to the bags. There were no traps or bait stations present in the area.  
Food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin 
infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls to allow for cleaning beneath and around 
the supplies. The licensee must also develop an effective pest control program to reduce contamination by pests in both 
animal and food storage areas. 
To be corrected by: January 23, 2026 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
An adult female poodle (Hershey, M/C number 901001000072972) has excessively long toenails on all four feet. The 
licensee stated that they did not have a set schedule for checking and trimming toenails on the dogs. An adult male 
poodle (Reuben, M/C number 933000321000501) also has excessively long nails on all four feet. Multiple large mats 
were present on both hind legs and feet. Matted coats may cause discomfort to the animal and result in irritation of the 
skin beneath the mats. Excessively long toenails are more likely to break or get caught in the grated flooring of the 
enclosure and result in injury. Long toenails can also result in pain and difficulty walking or standing normally.  
The current program of veterinary care states that both nails and haircoats are to be checked every 2 to 4 months.  
The licensee must follow their preventative care plan to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, 
and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The licensee must have these dogs groomed to address the long 
toenails and matting.  
To be corrected by: January 16, 2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
